newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Luxembourg to push for "indicative" euro rates.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg to push for "indicative" euro rates.

text.p: Luxembourg, which takes over the European Union presidency in July, will push quickly to set "indicative" exchange rates for European currencies against the single currency, Foreign Minister Jacques Poos said on Saturday.
The government wants to prevent market speculation from derailing the plan to introduce the euro in 1999, Poos said in an interview with the Belgian financial paper L'Echo.
"We cannot let the markets dictate political decisions that must be taken on the basis of economic data from the year 1997," he said.
EU states will decide in 1998 on the basis of that data which countries qualify to participate in the euro at the start.
"We can expect throughout that preparation period political discussions on, and reaction by financial markets to, all of the economic indicators of the countries likely to participate," Poos said.

A final decision on the rates for converting national currencies into euros cannot be taken until the new currency's membership is agreed. But Poos said "indicative" rates could cut down on market turmoil. -- Brussels newsroom, (322) 287 6800
